relationships.evidence_text: Welcome to the Y Honors Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry.
we're visiting with the founder of Capital Institute, John Fullerton.

relationships.relationship: unconventional economist, impact investor, writer, philosopher
relationships.evidence_text: John Fullerton is an unconventional economist, impact investor, writer and some have said philosopher.
He is the architect of regenerative economics first conceived in his 2015 booklet called regenerative capitalism.
first conceived in his 2015 booklet called regenerative capitalism.
John listened to a persistent inner voice and walked away in 2001 with no plan, but many questions.
A few months later, he experienced 9-11 firsthand.
the questions crystallized into his life's work with the creation of the Capital Institute in 2010.

relationships.target: the bold reimagination of economics and finance
relationships.evidence_text: Capital Institute is dedicated to the bold reimagination of economics and finance.

evidence.target_surface: the bold reimagination of economics and finance

relationships.evidence_text: guided by the universal patterns and principles that describe how all healthy living systems that sustain themselves in the real world actually work.

relationships.target: the profound and presently unseen potential
relationships.evidence_text: The promise of regenerative economics and finance is to unlock the profound and presently unseen potential.

evidence.target_surface: the profound and presently unseen potential

relationships.target: numerous capital markets and derivatives businesses
relationships.evidence_text: During his Wall Street career, John managed numerous capital markets and derivatives businesses around the globe.

evidence.target_surface: numerous capital markets and derivatives businesses

relationships.evidence_text: was JP Morgan's oversight committee representative that managed the rescue of long-term capital management in 1998.
was chief investment officer for Lab Morgan before retiring from the firm.
John is the chairman of New Day Enterprises, PBC.
and the co-founder of Grasslands LLC.
He is a board member of FirstCrop.
is a board member of the Savory Institute.
is a board member of Stoneaker's Farm.
is an advisor to numerous sustainability initiatives.
and is a member of the Club of Rome.
John speaks internationally to public audiences and universities.

to say what if we considered the human economy as a living system?

the way we use it today to grow the economy makes the problem worse.
If you have a system that is unsustainable and compounding, it is only a question of time.
As my friend Vincent Stanley likes to say when the way you go bankrupt slowly and then quickly.
You have articulated a framework that presents us an alternative pathway to the trajectory that we have been on for many decades, many generations now.
As my friend Vincent Stanley likes to say when the way you go bankrupt slowly and then quickly.
I would like to invite you if you would to walk us through the regenerative economic framework that you have articulated.
If you do not mind, speak to the 8 principles that identify and describe that framework.
the first and most important idea is to recognize the limitations of modern age scientific thinking.
which is this idea of the reductionist method, where we take what is complicated and reduce it into pieces and parts that we can get our heads around.
In many ways, whether you are talking about our healthcare system, our education system, our legal system, or our economy.
which was the key to the scientific revolution and all of the quote progress that we have made.
My colleague, Peter Brown, likes to say that economics is bankrupt.
It might be more accurate to say that economics is insolvenous.
Insolvency means where you have liabilities that become bigger than the assets.
the limitations and the flaws of our economic thinking are now so profound and so great that they outweigh the many considerable strengths that economic thinking has.
If you have a bankrupt way of thinking and seeing the world, you have to go back to first principles.
the core idea is to assume and assert that the human economy, which, after all, is made up of human beings, which are by definition living systems.
to assert that the human economy to be sustainable needs to behave the way other living systems behave.
the scientists who have studied living systems, while this is not as black and white as law of gravity, it is more complex.
But the living system scientists will concur or have concurred that there are general patterns and principles that describe the way living systems work.
the importance of symbiotic win-win relationships in living systems.
For example, the cells in every organ in our body are working in symbiotic relationship with each other and they become part of a bigger whole.
which again is part of a bigger whole called our human body.
And our human body isn't even all of us because there's the whole consciousness and spiritual piece of it and our self and our souls.
the idea is that the construct of living systems are these right relationships where the whole is greater than the sum of the parts.
the parts work toward the health of the whole.
There's no living system scientists that would disagree with what I just said.
